Description.val:
This line item funds modifications to T-45A/C aircraft.  The T-45 Goshawk is a tandem-seat, carrier capable derivative of the existing British Aerospace Hawk aircraft powered by a single Rolls Royce Adour engine.  It serves as the aircraft component of the T45TS integrated jet pilot training system which replaces the three decade old TA-4 and T-2 technology.  The overall goal of the modifications budgeted in FY 2014 is to correct discrepancies and deficiencies discovered after delivery of the aircraft and to commence upgrades to the aircraft cockpit and navigation systems.  T-45 aircraft and simulators are facing critical avionics obsolescence and Diminishing Manufacturing Source issues.  [Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP)] 08-95 (Corrections Of Deficiencies) was established to resolve safety and reliability issues, improve required mission capabilities, and increase service life of aircraft components.  OSIP 03-03 (Engine Surge) was established to resolve engine surge critical safety issues.  OSIP 17-04 (Avionics Obsolescence) was established to convert the T-45As (analog) to the digital T-45C configuration (Required Avionics Modernization Program) and resolve avionics obsolescence/DMSMS and safety related avionics issues.  OSIP (02-06) (Synthetic Radar) was established because the T-2/T-39 divestiture schedule (T-2 divested in 2008 and T-39 in 2015) and the training command requirement to continue Undergraduate Military Flight Officer training.  No new Type Model Series will be developed to pick up this requirement; as a result, the T-45 will modify 19 aircraft to incorporate Synthetic Radar Training into curriculum.  OSIP 022-14 was created to execute Service Life Extension Program from FY14 through the FYDP.

The designed service life of the aircraft is 14,400 hours with the average remaining service life of inventory aircraft estimated at 9,600 hours.

Justification.val: For OSD14 budget submit, the SLEP OSIP 022-14 was created to execute FY14 through the FYDP, it was previously under OSIP 08-95.  Non-Recurring Engineering for SLEP modifications will incorporate changes to improve structural details to increase aircraft service life to 21,600 flight hours at 150% Fatigue Life Expended which enables Chief of Naval Air Training pilot training requirements to be safely met until 2035. Task previously covered under OSIP 08-85 through FY13 and has been moved to SLEP OSIP 022-14 for FY14 through the FYDP.

ModificationType.val: Safety, Reliability, Increased Service Life, Improved Mission Capabilities

Description.val:
This OSIP funds correction of deficiencies discovered during test and evaluation or operational use to the entire airframe, its components and sub-assemblies, including related Support Equipment (SE), all of which vary in complexity and cost of Non-Recurring Engineering, procurement and installation.  The correction of deficiencies Engineering Change Proposals (ECPs) include, but are not limited to: AIRFRAME ECPs - divided into two categories; Structural and Systems.  STRUCTURAL ECPs: The structural portion of this OSIP provides for several structural ECPs to correct safety of flight related issues and deficiencies in meeting airframe original design life of 14,400 Flight Hours.  ECPs for Wing Leading Edge panels, Wing centerline joint, Flap Center Hinge Arm, Canopy frame, Canopy Frame Longeron, Wing tip, Gas Turbine Starter bracket, Horizontal Stabilators, Frame 24 Crossbeam Lugs and Side Skin, Frame 7 Upper Cross Tie, Wing Leading Edge, Frame 29 Lower Flange, Uplock Beam Forward Attach, Slat Track Rib 5 Downstop Bolt, Rib 2 T-Clip, Frame 28/32 Boundary/Vertical Fin, Frame 33 Structure, Inlet Close-Out Fuel and Tank Ceiling Stiffener, Airframe Engine Mount, Frame 21 Structure, Main Landing Gear (MLG) Bay Tilted & Fasteners, MLG Side Stay Support, Longitudinal Systems Viscous, Frame 20 Lower Longeron/Sidebrace, Frame 12 Vertical Splice, Frame 1 Structures and Ballast provisions, Nose Landing Gear Trunnion Beam, Slat Actuator Fitting Angle, Structure Life Improvement, Speed Brake and Backup Structure, Engine Mount Link Option, Stabilizer Back-Up Structures, Fuselage/Frame 10 Door, and Fin Bracket Lever Box Assembly, Over Center Locking Mechanism, Arrestor Beam Back-up Structure, Wing Lower Aux Spar Doubler, Frame 16 Lateral Link, Frame 17/18 structures and Fuselage Sideskin Fasteners.  SYSTEMS ECPs: Modifications to the airframe, other than structural deficiencies, are also required to ensure safety of flight, aero-performance and maintainability to enable satisfactory Pilot Training Requirements levels.  This Airframe OSIP affects several airframe components and their sub-assemblies including:  forward, center and aft fuselage components, Landing Gear, Nose Wheel Steering, arresting hook, tail cone, wing, horizontal and vertical control surfaces, flaps, canopy/windscreen, Aircrew Systems, Ejection system, including lanyard retention collar, ejection control handle, sequencer, barostatic release unit, seat pan, head box and associated components,  hydraulic system, and hyd system quick disconnects, oxygen system to include oxygen  monitor, concentrator, and ancillary components, electrical system, fuel system, throttle, instrumentation systems, environmental controls, communications, navigation, emergency systems, and associated Support Equipment (SE) to include Peculiar Support Equipment (PSE), nosewheel steering tester, hydraulic test stand, cabin pressure test set, Easily Manipulated Mechanical Arm, frame 33 tail plane fitting tool,  and  landing gear (dummy gear).  AVIONICS/GROUND BASED TRAINING SYSTEMS:  Modifications to the Avionics will be required to update the Display Unit, Heads-Up Display, Global Positioning System, Inertial Navigation Assembly and those avionic components associated with the affected aircraft systems. The following Avionics ECPs include: Digital Data System, Almanac Loading System, Mission Computer, communication systems, navigation systems, including Radar Altimeter, inverter, and associated SE.  ENGINE/POWER AND PROPULSION:  Modifications under this category include modifications to the Engine, Gas Turbine Starter, and Electrical System which will increase the reliability, maintainability and safety of these systems.  Engine modifications include Engine Mounts, Fuel Pumps, Combustion Chamber, Compressors, Nozzle Guide Vanes, Drive Systems, Oil System, Air Systems, Turbines, Fuel Distribution and Control and modifications to address engine surge/compressor stall. Gas Turbine Starter modifications include starting system, air turbine starter, and air producer.  Electrical modifications include generator/distribution/wiring modifications.  Service Life Extension Programs (SLEP):  During Full Scale Development testing of the T45 aircraft it was determined that incorporation of redesigned components applicable to the critical load paths will significantly increase the service life of the aircraft.  Correcting these areas is required to achieve the safe design life associated with the program of record.  The additional other support and Non-Recurring Engineering costs in FY-14 and beyond (started in FY-13) are to fund Government labor to perform engineering, test, logistics and financial management tasks, and to execute, oversee and administer contracts across the T-45 program, including existing efforts.


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  FY-13 provides funds for STRUCTURAL ECPs, SYSTEMS ECPs, AVIONICS ECPs, and ENGINE/PROPULSION & POWER ECPs. FY-14 provides funds for STRUCTURAL ECPs, SYSTEMS ECPs, AVIONICS ECPs, and ENGINE/PROPULSION & POWER ECPs.  Non-Recurring Engineering for SLEP modifications will incorporate changes to improve structural details to increase aircraft service life to 21,600 flight hours at 150% Fatigue Life Expended which enables Chief of Naval Air Training pilot training requirements to be safely met until 2035. Task previously covered under OSIP 08-95 through FY13 and has been moved to SLEP OSIP 022-14 for FY14 through the FYDP.

Task previously covered under OSIP 08-95 and has been moved to SLEP OSIP 022-14 for FY14 through the FYDP.

In previous budgets the following efforts were rolled up under Airframe Systems Cost Element: Main Landing Gear HY-TUF Kits, Hookshank LSP, Hookshank New Vender, Nose Wheel Steering System, Hydraulic System, and Naces Lanyard Retention Collar.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Organic - Engine Kits O & I Level

Description.val:
Engine Surge:  T-45 engine surge is a critical safety concern for a single engine aircraft with over 450 surge events documented, including over 70 surges requiring engine shutdown and restart emergency action.  Funding was provided to correct T-45 F405 engine surge/stall. Kits include modifications to air vehicle, engine, and fuel control system.  Non-Recurring Engineering efforts to modify air vehicle and engine components will occur in FY14 to support kit procurements in FY15.  Starting in FY14, Office of the Chief of Naval Operations Issue 50104 provided an additional $39.1M within FY14-FY18 to fund T-45 Engine Inlet Modification efforts to mitigate surge/stall risk to an acceptable level.  T-45 Engine Inlet Modification Non-Recurring Engineering will occur in FY14-FY16 to support kit procurements beginning in FY16.  Naval Air Systems Command/Airforces will not accept engine stall risk without Program Objective Memorandum 14 mitigation efforts.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Funding was provided to correct T-45 F405 engine surge.  Non-Recurring Engineering efforts to modify the F405-401 engine will continue in FY14 to support kit procurement in FY16.

In DON14, FY13 DDS Increment I CE 1.1.3 was not broken out and was under Osolescence Kit CE 1.1.2.  Previously Obsolesence Kits CE 1.1.2 consisted of 200 AKits. Those Kits are now accurately reflected as 127 MFCD (BKits) and 17 DDS Increment I (Akits/BKits). The remaining 39 units were erroneously reported.  This comment also address CE 2.1.7, CE 2.1.11.  FY13, FY14 and FY15 install schedule has prior year buys of 275 and FY12 buys of 61.
RAMP kits had an ALT of 12 months and PLT of 24 Months.  All other installations are various MFG, contract dates and ALT/PLT.

Description.val:
The T-45TS is facing critical obsolescence/performance issues.  Components of various avionics boxes will not be supportable as a result of Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) issues that result in part obsolescence or supplier mortality.   

The Required Avionics Modernization Program (RAMP) is the Analog to Digital conversion of the T-45A aircraft.   RAMP was intended to resolve obsolescence issues with such items as the Global Inertial Navigation Assembly (GINA) (Field Programmable Gate Array and Processor), Display Processor (DP) (Diode), Airborne Data Recorder (ADR) (Line in Buffer Amplifier), Multi-Function Display (MFD), Signal Data Computer (SDC), Azmith Computer, and various other avionics computers. 

The RAMP effort itself consists of a Glass Cockpit upgrade which includes two (2) Multi-Function Color Displays (MFCD) per cockpit, a Mission Display Processor (MDP), Stability Augmentation Data Sensor (SADS), Replacement recorder (ASDC), Pilot Display Unit (PDU), Fuel Flow Indicator (FFI), associated cockpit controls and a 1553 digital data bus; integrating them with the existing Heads Up Display, the ADR, and a separately procured GINA.  

As a continued effort to address sustainment, obsolescence and performance issues, the Digital Data Set (DDS) is being introduced to the T-45 by replacing the Mission Data Loader, Airborne Video Cassette Recorder, Aircraft Data Recorders (ADR, SDC, ASDC) on each aircraft.  The DDS, which includes the Digitial Acquisition Unit, the Control Panel (CP), and associated wiring, will be installed on all T-45C aircraft.

AVIONICS/GROUND BASED TRAINING SYSTEMS:  Modifications to the Avionics will be required to update the Display Unit, Heads-Up Display, Global Positioning System, Inertial Navigation Assembly and those avionic components associated with the affected aircraft systems.  The following Avionics ECPs include: Almanac Loading System, communication systems, navigation systems, including Radar Altimeter, inverter, and associated SE.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: FY13 provides funds for MFCD and DDS procurement kits.  FY14 provides funds for MFCD and DDS procurement kits. 

Beginning in FY13, Avionics and GBTS lines removed from OSIP 08-95  and added to OSIP 17-04 to better align these requirements to the proper OSIP.

Name.@footnote: Due to the HAC mark, we are unable to revise FY13 to show the correct split between "A" and "B" kits.
Contract and Delivery dates are various

Description.val:
With the T-2 and T-39 divestiture in 2008 and 2012 respectively, the training command cannot complete Uniformed Military Flight Officer training.  No new Type Model Series will be developed to pick up this requirement.  As a result, the T-45 will modify 19 aircraft to incorporate Virtual Mission Training System (VMTS) into the curriculum.  The effort will include two phases of integration to incorporate a commercial off the shelf synthetic radar system into the T-45.  Phase I includes determining the integration requirements for the air-to-air and minimal air-to-ground (A/G) synthetic radar capabilities and completing the T-45 integration effort.   Phase II includes determining the integration requirements for increased A/G fidelity simulation and weapons sensors simulation while also completing the Phase II integration effort.  Four kits will be utilized for testing and will initially be delivered to Pensacola for Instructor training and syllabus evaluation. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  FY07-11 provided funding for 2 prototypes, non-recurring engineering, and 3 follow-on test and evaluation kits.  FY12 provided funding for 12 procurement kits that require a 12 month lead time before delivery.  FY13 provides funding for the procurement of the remaining kits and installation of the 12 kits. FY14 provides funding for the installation of the remaining 5 kits.

ModificationType.val: Safety, Reliability, Increased Service Life, Improved Mission Capabilities

Description.val:
This OSIP funds correction of deficiencies discovered in Service Life Assessment Program (SLAP) which identified risk areas that must be addressed in order to extend aircraft service life. Service Life Extension Programs (SLEP):  During Full Scale Development testing of the T45 aircraft it was determined that incorporation of redesigned components applicable to the critical load paths will significantly increase the service life of the aircraft.  Correcting these areas is required to achieve the safe design life associated with the program of record.  Non-Recurring Engineering for SLEP modifications will incorporate changes to improve subsystem and structural details to increase aircraft service life to 21,600 flight hours at 150% FLE which enables CNATRA pilot training requirements to be safely met until 2035. The additional other support and Non-Recurring Engineering costs in FY-14 and beyond (started in FY-13) are to fund Government labor to perform engineering, test, logistics and financial management tasks, and to execute, oversee and administer contracts across the T-45 structural and subsystems SLEP program, including existing efforts.

Development Status/Major Milestones:  For OSD14 budget submit, the SLEP OSIP 022-14 was created to execute FY14 through the FYDP, it was previously under OSIP 08-95.  Non-Recurring Engineering for SLEP modifications will incorporate changes to improve structural details to increase aircraft service life to 21,600 flight hours at 150% Fatigue Life Expended which enables Chief of Naval Air Training pilot training requirements to be safely met until 2035. Task previously covered under OSIP 08-95 through FY13 and has been moved to SLEP OSIP 022-14 for FY14 through the FYDP.
